Our Thanksgiving gathering at Daniel's Broiler, set against the backdrop of the bar, followed a straightforward culinary narrative. My companion opted for the classic turkey, while I leaned towards the prime rib. The gustatory experience was undeniably praiseworthy, with flavors that underscored a notable culinary finesse.Service, operating within the parameters of adequacy, maintained an understated demeanor, providing a seamless backdrop to our dining experience.However, the post-dinner endeavor to secure leftovers took an unforeseen turn. A meticulous separation of meat and fat, coupled with a modest request for an extra serving of potatoes, aimed to prolong the culinary pleasure. Regrettably, upon revisiting the remains, the gastronomic continuity suffered a setback. The boxed ensemble, lacking cranberry sauce, horseradish that had been left on my plate, and the absent side of coveted potatoes I requested, presented a major Thanksgiving leftovers letdown---especially taking into consideration the high price we had paid for the meal. Nevertheless, let this culinary service anomaly not overshadow the overall commendable nature of the experience. As we contemplate future visits, a pragmatic approach emerges - a proactive request during the boxing process to ensure a more faithful representation of the intended leftovers. Here's to culinary precision and anticipating an untarnished encore in subsequent engagements.

Piroshky Piroshky is a Seattle institution and a must-visit for anyone exploring Pike Place Market. This small, bustling bakery offers an incredible selection of hand-held pastries that are as delicious as they are iconic.I tried the Smoked Salmon Pate Piroshky, and it was everything I hoped for and more. The pastry itself was flaky, golden, and baked to perfection, while the filling was rich, flavorful, and packed with high-quality smoked salmon. The balance of buttery dough and savory filling made every bite unforgettable.Be prepared for a line--it's a testament to how beloved this spot is. But trust me, the wait is worth it. The staff works quickly and efficiently, and the pastries are always fresh out of the oven.Whether you're grabbing a quick bite while exploring Pike Place or looking for a unique Seattle treat to take home, Piroshky Piroshky delivers an authentic and satisfying experience.

Basically bread with stuff .. stuffed inside lol. Carb heaven I must say. Everything has bread with it. Therefore, if you cannot eat carbs or it's a weakness for you, stay away lol. I ended up getting the Smoked Salmon Pate. Giving the traditional Piroshky a local spin, this bestseller is a delicious blend of Smoked Salmon, cream cheese, a dash of dill and onion. I really loved it. It was nice and warm and the smoked salmon was flavorful.Then during a food tour, I had the Smoked Salmon Pate and then an Apple Cinnamon Roll. This includes slices of Granny Smith Apples dusted with Cinnamon, rolled into dough and finished with a glaze of honey and lemon. It is their bestselling sweet creation. It was really good.The morning we had to run to the airport, we ended up coming back. I had the Spinach, Egg, and Cheese. It contained Spinach tossed with Parmesan then baked with egg. Piroshky Piroshky is a gem tucked away in Pike Place Market, and a must-visit on any Seattle trip. This charming bakery is known for its diverse and flavorful piroshkies, and it certainly lives up to its reputation.My personal favorite was the cheese and meat piroshky - a warm, hearty parcel filled with aromatic spices. It was the perfect way to kick-start our day of exploration. The taste still lingers in my memory, making me crave another bite.Another standout item was the Vatrushka, a house specialty. This delectable treat consists of house-made dough topped with marionberries & sweet cream cheese, all dusted with powdered sugar. It was sweet without being cloying, and the marionberries added a delightful tanginess that played off the creamy cheese perfectly.Don't let the line intimidate you - Piroshky Piroshky is more than worth the wait. In fact, the anticipation only adds to the experience. As I pen this review, I find myself longing to be back there again, savoring those incredible flavors.Piroshky Piroshky offers an authentic, delicious taste of Seattle that you won't want to miss. Whether you're a local or a visitor, this place should be at the top of your foodie list.

The piroshky have amazing crusts, and then filled with flavors such as salmon, broccoli cheese, and cream of mushroom, and sweet Piroshky such as rhubarb and chocolate. There seem to be different types of crust for different types of fillings. I find two savory and one sweet piroshky splits well between 2 people.You will need to stand in line, or go on a slow day (some weekday during the winter when the skies are dark). Then, there is not seating, so you will have to take your piroshky and flee to somewhere more comfortable. If you explore Pike Place, you will find that there is public seating available, or coffee shops you can occupy. If you go straight back and to the left of the Piroshky place, you can find some small amount of public seating, and if that is full, across the street there is a nice park (although someone tried to sell me drugs last time I went there, which might make tourists more uncomfortable).You might wonder if this hassle is worth it. theres a reason why people love these local of places of lore. the kind of places that have been made famous by their history, simplicity and loyalty to a product that is distinctly local in flavor. despite the fact that they have been washed over by waves and waves of tourists, these places are still able to maintain their sense of indivuduality by marketing to a uniquely regional appeal. when i first moved to seattle i went looking for that regional treat. that one comfort food that cannot be replicated anywhere else (read: philly cheesesteaks at geno's, wings at buffalo's anchor bar, bens chili bowl in dc). i and many others would believe that that place can be found at piroshky piroshky.purists can talk all they want about how close to the original recipe they may be, what resonates with these delicious russian treats is a taste of home, even if it isnt orignally yours. piroshky piroshky is a cheap, delicious treat that maks any day in the market all the more rewarding. for four dollars (5 with a cup of coffee) grab a warm, flaky, salty and fulfilling meat and cheese pastry and enjoy it at steinbrueck park while you watch the boats float in. nothing could be better on a lazy morning.

Von's 1000 Spirit's is a haven to anyone looking to escape the mundane. As soon as I walked in the door, I was greated by a lovely young host. I think her name was Zia? She took the time to find accommodations for my group. There were 6 of us on a busy Friday night, yet she was able to find us a table almost immediately, to our delight. Our server, Elizabeth, was a wealth of knowledge on their spirit collection ( Yes they really have over 1 thousand) and was able to recommend each of us great drinks to try. Having already been impressed, to food left me speechless. Their "Mac n 4 cheeses" was decadent. The perfect amount of rich, not to mention how delicious their house made sourdough pasta is! My wife had Avocado Bacon burger and was equally satisfied. It safe to say me and my family will be back soon!

You won't be finding any IMPASTAs here! Their sourdough pesto pasta was delicious! What I really appreciated was that our server, Traci, took the time to explain all her favorite key dishes to us when we were having difficulty deciding over the incredible menu choices.What really stood out to me as a patron was the care she took with our kids at the table. My daughter loves mac and cheese but there was no option for it on the kids menu. Without hesitation Traci said she could modify a kids pasta to make as mac and cheese. She did give warning that the mac and cheese would be a bit spicy but my daughter was elated at the idea of mac and cheese. Wouldn't you know it, as children do, my daughter changed her mind after one bite. Apologetically I explained the situation to our server when she came to the table after the food was delivered. Traci was more than happy to replace my child's meal with an alternative cream sauce, which my daughter loved, and the new dish was out within minutes of my request. As a parent it is always an adventure to go out with your children because you can never anticipate how long their attention will be kept before they are ALL DONE and want to move on. I was extremely impressed and thankful for the care and understanding our server took to make sure everyone at my table enjoyed their meal. Even though Von's has 1000 spirits and seems to cater to an older crowd I still left feeling it was a family-friendly restaurant as well.

I love this place. I drive all the way into Seattle just to go here which is about 20 minutes out. When I think about going to Pike's, I know Von's is waiting. I love the decor, the lighting, the food, the drinks..........AND, dun da da DAAAAAhhhhh, the beignet's are little cushions of happy. I was out and about doing some photography when started to get a little hungry, plus it was beer-thirty. The glowing sign peeked out and caught my attention. I went in to order a stout and the cinnamon sugar beignets and from that moment I was hooked. I knew, just from the menu, there was more deliciousness to come. I wasn't wrong.  They have an aged old eloquent selection of liquors on a lovely glass shelf with little cards that indicate what it is and pricing, plus a full bar, and nice beer on tap. They have really good cocktails and it's always fun to spin the wheel and see what you can get a discount on for the next thirty minutes. The staff is really nice and accommodating and I just have the best time when I go in there. The burgers are unique and good, the pizza is amazing, the pasta is delicious, and the salmon soup/stew with a nice chunk of sourdough soaking in the bowl is heavenly. I've ordered that twice. It's just great and I'm running out of adjectives to describe it. Just go in, sit down, and enjoy yourself.
